title: Two objects. Same room. Two different temperatures?

multiple-choice.question: What does the sensation of warmth or coldness tell you about an object when you touch it?

options.label: A
options.text: The actual temperature of the object

options.label: B
options.text: The rate at which heat is conducted towards or away from you

options.label: C
options.text: The material composition of the object

multiple-choice.question: Why did the aluminium block feel colder than the plastic block, even though they were at the same temperature?

options.label: A
options.text: Because aluminium is a better insulator than plastic

options.label: B
options.text: Because aluminium is a worse conductor of heat than plastic

options.label: C
options.text: Because aluminium conducts heat away from your hand faster than plastic

options.label: D
options.text: Because aluminium is a more dense material than plastic

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the rate at which heat is transferred from one object to another?
Why does the bath mat feel warmer than the towel beside it after a shower in winter?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the bath mat is actually warmer than the towel

options.label: B
options.text: Because the bath mat conducts heat less quickly away from you than the towel

options.label: C
options.text: Because the bath mat is made of a more insulating material than the towel

options.label: D
options.text: Because the bath mat is closer to the showerhead than the towel

multiple-choice.question: What happened to the ice cube on the aluminium block compared to the plastic block?

options.label: A
options.text: It melted more slowly on the aluminium block

options.label: B
options.text: It melted at the same rate on both blocks

options.label: C
options.text: It melted more quickly on the aluminium block

options.label: D
options.text: It didn't melt at all on the aluminium block

title: How the mantis shrimp can break glass

multiple-choice.question: What is the shape of the structure located on top of the mantis shrimp's smasher, which is responsible for its powerful punch?
According to the video, what is the primary mechanism that allows the mantis shrimp to punch with such high velocity?

options.label: C
options.text: Release of stored mechanical strain energy

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the organic polymer that makes up the mantis shrimp's smasher, which provides strength in multiple directions?
What is unique about the composition of the mantis shrimp's smasher, as discovered by the team at the Wyss Institute?

options.label: B
options.text: The material changes composition and strength at different locations

options.label: C
options.text: The material is made up of identical layers stacked together

options.label: D
options.text: The material is only strong in one direction

multiple-choice.question: What is special about the way the mantis shrimp's smasher is structured, allowing it to distribute the force of impact?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a uniform composite material

options.label: B
options.text: It is a variable composite material

options.label: C
options.text: It is made up of a single layer of material

options.label: D
options.text: It is only strong at the surface

title: Making a TED-Ed Lesson: Bringing a pop-up book to life

multiple-choice.question: What was the idea behind creating a pop-up book to explain Earth's tectonic plates?

options.label: A
options.text: To show the movement of the plates using a tangible object

options.label: B
options.text: To create a detailed illustration of the plates

options.label: C
options.text: To depict the plates using a digital animation

options.label: D
options.text: To show the history of the plates

multiple-choice.question: What are the two types of folds that can make elements pop up in a pop-up book?

options.label: B
options.text: To visualize the pop-up and plan each movement

options.label: C
options.text: To make adjustments and see how the preliminary sketches come to life

multiple-choice.question: What was used to move the clouds across the page in the stop-motion animation?
What was the final step in creating the pop-up book animation?

options.label: D
options.text: Compositing the individual frames to make the pop-up book look like it's moving on its own

title: Can You Solve This?

multiple-choice.question: What was the rule that the speaker had in mind for the three-number sequence?

options.label: A
options.text: By proposing numbers that didn't fit their initial hypothesis

options.label: B
options.text: By proposing numbers that fit their initial hypothesis

options.label: C
options.text: By asking the speaker for a hint

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of proving a theory true

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's advice for getting at the truth?
What is the key aspect of the scientific method highlighted by the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of proving a theory true

options.label: B
options.text: The need to disprove alternative theories

options.label: C
options.text: The role of intuition in scientific discovery

options.label: D

title: The science of the Game of Thrones

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason for the unpredictable seasons in the Game of Thrones universe?

options.label: A
options.text: The planet's axial tilt is unstable due to the lack of a large moon.

options.label: B
options.text: The planet's orbit is extremely elongated, causing extreme seasons.

options.label: C
options.text: The planet is likely in a binary star system, making it difficult to predict seasons.

options.label: D
options.text: The planet's sun has a variable output, affecting the seasons.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the estimated radius of the Game of Thrones planet, also known as Planet Hodor?
What is the inspiration behind Valyrian steel in the Game of Thrones universe?

options.label: A
options.text: Damascus steel, an ancient steel alloy developed in India.

options.label: B
options.text: Greek Fire, an ancient precursor to napalm.

options.label: C
options.text: Dragon fire, a mythical concept in the Game of Thrones universe.

options.label: D
options.text: Wildfire, a potent weapon in the Game of Thrones universe.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the largest bird that ever lived, and how does it compare to the size of Daenerys' dragons?

options.label: A
options.text: The giant teratorn, with a wingspan of 7 meters, which is larger than Daenerys' dragons.

options.label: B
options.text: The giant teratorn, with a wingspan of 7 meters, which is smaller than Daenerys' dragons.

options.label: C
options.text: The Quetzalcoatlus, with a wingspan of 11 meters, which is larger than Daenerys' dragons.

options.label: D
options.text: The Quetzalcoatlus, with a wingspan of 11 meters, which is smaller than Daenerys' dragons.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept behind the Wall in the Game of Thrones universe, and why wouldn't it work in reality?

options.label: A
options.text: The Wall is a sheer cliff of solid ice, and it wouldn't work because it would melt at the bottom under its own weight.

options.label: B
options.text: The Wall is a structure made of stone, and it wouldn't work because it would be too expensive to build.

options.label: C
options.text: The Wall is a magical barrier, and it wouldn't work because magic isn't real.

options.label: D
options.text: The Wall is a natural formation, and it wouldn't work because it would be too difficult to maintain.

title: World War II: Why is it so important decades later?

options.label: C
options.text: The colonies wanted to impose taxes on Great Britain.

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: It inspired other revolutions and shaped modern democracy.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: It had no significant impact on world history.

multiple-choice.question: How many milliliters of gas does a person typically produce daily?

options.label: B

title: Corruption, wealth and beauty: The history of the Venetian gondola - Laura Morelli

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary mode of transportation in Venice, Italy in the 1500s?
Why did Venetian authorities decree that all but ceremonial gondolas be painted black in 1562?

options.label: B
options.text: To make gondolas more visible in the canals

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the speed of gondola travel

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary material used to construct gondolas?

options.label: A
options.text: Beech, cherry, elm, fir, larch, lime, mahogany, oak, and walnut

options.label: A
options.text: To steer the gondola from the left side

options.label: B
options.text: To guide the oar into many positions

options.label: C
options.text: To increase the speed of gondola travel

options.label: D
options.text: To decrease the weight of the gondola

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: To increase the speed of gondola travel

options.label: C

title: What if the Earth stopped spinning?

multiple-choice.question: What would happen to a person's weight if the Earth suddenly stopped spinning?

options.label: C
options.text: Their weight would remain the same

options.label: A
options.text: They would continue to rotate with the Earth

options.label: B
options.text: They would surge onto land in tsunamis kilometers high

options.label: B
options.text: The change in velocity is too gradual

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The Earth's rotation is too fast

title: What happens when you remove the hippocampus? - Sam Kean

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary goal of Dr. Scoville's surgery on H.M.?
What was the unexpected outcome of H.M.'s surgery?

options.label: D
options.text: He was unable to form new memories

multiple-choice.question: What did Brenda Milner's research on H.M. reveal about memory?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is a single, unified system

options.label: B
options.text: That it is localized to a specific brain region

options.label: C
options.text: That it can be divided into short-term and long-term memory

options.label: D
options.text: That it is not affected by brain damage

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the hippocampus in memory formation?

options.label: C
options.text: To transfer memories to the cortex for permanent storage

multiple-choice.question: What is the distinction between declarative and procedural memory?

options.label: A
options.text: Declarative memory refers to skills and habits, while procedural memory refers to facts and knowledge

options.label: B
options.text: Declarative memory refers to facts and knowledge, while procedural memory refers to skills and habits

options.label: C
options.text: Declarative memory refers to short-term memory, while procedural memory refers to long-term memory

options.label: D
options.text: Declarative memory refers to conscious memory, while procedural memory refers to unconscious memory

title: Feedback loops: How nature gets its rhythms - Anje-Margriet Neutel

multiple-choice.question: What is the key element of feedback in the environment or social science?

options.label: A
options.text: A phenomenon called mutual exclusive interaction

options.label: B
options.text: A phenomenon called mutual causal interaction

options.label: C
options.text: A phenomenon called internal feedback loop

options.label: D
options.text: A phenomenon called external feedback loop

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of positive feedback in an ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: When plants die, the dead material depletes the soil of humus

options.label: B
options.text: When plants die, the dead material enriches the soil with humus

options.label: C
options.text: When predators eat prey, they increase their population

options.label: D
options.text: When predators eat prey, they reduce their population

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of negative feedback in an ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: It amplifies changes in the ecosystem

options.label: B
options.text: It diminishes or counteracts changes in the ecosystem

options.label: C
options.text: It maintains a stable balance in the ecosystem

options.label: D
options.text: It disrupts the balance in the ecosystem

multiple-choice.question: What happens when a link is removed from a feedback loop?
What is the result of wide-ranging negative feedbacks in an ecosystem?

options.label: B
options.text: They keep positive feedbacks in check

options.label: C
options.text: They disrupt the balance in the ecosystem

options.label: D
options.text: They maintain a stable balance in the ecosystem

title: What can Schrödinger's cat teach us about quantum mechanics? - Josh Samani

multiple-choice.question: What type of physics governs the behavior of systems at the scale of atoms?
In the thought experiment of Schrödinger's cat, what is the state of the cat before the box is opened?

options.label: C
options.text: A mixture of both possibilities (superposition state)

What is the outcome of the Schrödinger's cat experiment with two cats in two different boxes, where the states of the cats are entangled?

options.label: C
options.text: One cat will be alive and the other cat will be dead

options.label: D
options.text: The outcome is random and unpredictable

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential application of quantum entanglement in the field of quantum information science?

title: Should I stay or should I switch doors?

multiple-choice.question: In the game show "Let's Make a Deal," what is the probability of winning the car if you stick with your initial choice?

options.text: Switch to the other unopened door

options.text: You will win the car 2/3 of the time

options.text: You will win the car 1/2 of the time

options.text: You will win the car every time

title: The past, present and future of the bubonic plague - Sharon N. DeWitte

multiple-choice.question: What was the estimated percentage of Europeans killed by the Black Death in the 14th century?

options.label: A
options.text: The disease was spread by rodent fleas

options.label: B
options.text: The disease was communicated directly from one person to another

options.label: C
options.text: The disease was spread through contaminated water

options.label: D
options.text: The disease was spread through poor sanitation

options.label: A
options.text: Wages decreased, and living standards declined

options.label: B
options.text: Wages increased, and living standards improved

options.label: D
options.text: The economy declined, but living standards improved

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: How optical illusions trick your brain - Nathan S. Jacobs

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why our brains are tricked by optical illusions?

options.label: B
options.text: Because our brains make assumptions about visual information

options.label: C
options.text: Because the images themselves are magical

options.label: D
options.text: Because we are not paying attention

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of retinal ganglion cells in our visual system?

options.label: B
options.text: To increase contrast with lateral inhibition

multiple-choice.question: Why do we tend to recognize faces quickly?

options.label: A
options.text: Because we are afraid of strangers

options.label: B
options.text: Because we are social animals and need to interact with each other

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the area in the brain that is specifically evolved to help us recognize faces?
Why does our brain use assumptions about visual information to construct a world on the fly?

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is busy and needs to allocate cognitive energy efficiently

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is not capable of processing all visual information

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is not interested in visual information

title: The secret lives of baby fish - Amy McDermott

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the Earth's surface is made up of coral reefs, which are home to over a quarter of the 27,000 known fish species?
How do baby coral reef fish larvae obtain oxygen when they first emerge and do not have gills yet?

options.label: A
options.text: By absorbing it from the water through their skin

options.label: B
options.text: By using their mouth to gulp air

options.label: C
options.text: By using their fins to extract oxygen from the water

options.label: D
options.text: By relying on stored oxygen in their bodies

multiple-choice.question: According to recent research, what is one way that larval fish may be able to maximize their chances of survival?

options.label: A
options.text: By drifting passively with ocean currents

options.label: B
options.text: By using their sense of smell to navigate

options.label: C
options.text: By moving vertically in the water column to place themselves in different water masses

multiple-choice.question: What sensory system do larvae use to distinguish between different environments and guide themselves toward their preferred adult habitats?

options.label: A
options.text: They drop down to the reef and settle immediately

options.label: B
options.text: They use a "bungee system" to check out the reef and then jump back up if conditions aren't right

options.label: C
options.text: They swim around the reef multiple times before settling

options.label: D
